abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory with project outcome likely. Both World Bank
            and Borrower performance were generally satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: Traditional systems of woodland
            management are strengthened by working with villagers to
            protect and conserve these resources themselves and through
            socio-legal mechanisms which villagers themselves control
            and maintain. Community involvement in joint forest
            management of government reserves can lead to improving the
            condition of reserves; pilot approaches could be
            strengthened by transferring decisionmaking more fully to
            the communities involved. Dry woodland management poses good
            opportunities because of the resilience of the woodland to
            harvesting, the cost-effectiveness of relying on natural
            regeneration with minimal silvicultural treatments, and the
            few risks to the environment posed by sustainable management
            of dry woodland ecosystems. Adopting the farmers'
            simple technologies is more apt than relying on high-tech
            approaches. Community participation in surveying village
            lands is essential and cost-effective since it reduced
            litigation, leading to considerable savings in time and
            resources. When project identification and preparation is
            bolstered by strategic studies, action-oriented research,
            and ESW, there are significant benefits. Future investments
            will likely be jeopardized without institutional reform.
            Technical supervision of advisory services needs to be
            strengthened and supported.

18157334.trustfund:
TF021070-SWEDISH (SIDA) CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF028120-UK-TANZANIA AGRICULTURAL
            ADJUSTMENT PRO.,TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF026790-FOREST RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROJECT
18157334.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The broad objective of the project is to
            support the implementation of the Tanzania Tropical Forestry
            Action Plan (TFAP) by strengthening the capacity of the
            institutions in charge of developing and implementing forest
            and land policies and by increasing the participation of the
            private sector and local populations in the management of
            natural resources in Tanzania.  The project includes the
            following components:  (a) strengthening of the natural
            resources monitoring and forest policies; (b) strengthening
            of land policies and institutions; and (c) strengthening of
            regional and district forest services in Mwanza and Tabora
            regions.  The first component will support the collection of
            natural resource information and development of a natural
            resource information system; development and implementation
            of improved practices for royalty collection and for
            afforestation based on private sector nurseries and active
            participation from local people; and preparation of an
            action plan for the long-term financing of the forestry
            subsector.  The second component will support the
            development of land policies and government's ongoing
            program of village demarcation, titling, and registration;
            and the third component will support the development of
            regional forest management plans and associated forest
            service reorganization and training.
